material.mattext: Information security’s primary mission is to ensure that systems and their contents retain their confidentiality at all costs.
Information security safeguards the technology assets in use at the organization.
A firewall is a mechanism that keeps certain kinds of network traffic out of a private network.

An act of theft performed by a hacker falls into the category of “theft,” but is also often accompanied by defacement actions to delay discovery and thus may also be placed within the category of “forces of nature.”
Two watchdog organizations that investigate allegations of software abuse: SIIA and NSA.
A number of technical mechanisms—digital watermarks and embedded code, copyright codes, and even the intentional placement of bad sectors on software media—have been used to enforce copyright laws.
A worm requires that another program is running before it can begin functioning.
A worm can deposit copies of itself onto all Web servers that the infected system can reach, so that users who subsequently visit those sites become infected.
Attacks conducted by scripts are usually unpredictable.
l0. Expert hackers are extremely talented individuals who usually devote lots of time and energy to attempting to break into other people’s information systems.
ll. With the removal of copyright protection, software can be easily distributed and installed.
l2. Forces of nature, force majeure, or acts of God can present some of the most dangerous threats, because they are usually occur with very little warning and are beyond the control of people.
l3. Much human error or failure can be prevented with training and ongoing awareness activities.
l4. Compared to Web site defacement, vandalism within a network is less malicious in intent and more public.
l5. With electronic information is stolen, the crime is readily apparent.
l6. Organizations can use dictionaries to disallow passwords during the reset process and thus guard against easy-to-guess passwords.
l7. DoS attacks cannot be launched against routers.
l8. A mail bomb is a form of DoS.

l9. A sniffer program shows all the data going by on a network segment including passwords, the data inside files—such as word-processing documents—and screens full of sensitive data from applications.
A timing attack involves the interception of cryptographic elements to determine keys and encryption algorithms.
2l. Intellectual property is defined as “the ownership of ideas and control over the tangible or virtual representation of those ideas.”
The macro virus infects the key operating system files located in a computer’s boot sector.
Once a(n) back door has infected a computer, it can redistribute itself to all e-mail addresses found on the infected system.
A(n) polymorphic threat is one that over time changes the way it appears to antivirus software programs, making it undetectable by techniques that look for preconfigured signatures.
When voltage levels surge (experience a momentary increase), the extra voltage can severely damage or destroy equipment.

The shoulder looking technique is used in public or semipublic settings when individuals gather information they are not authorized to have by looking over another individual’s shoulder or viewing the information from a distance.
Hackers are “people who use and create computer software to gain access to information illegally.”
Packet kiddies use automated exploits to engage in distributed denial-of-service attacks.
The term phreaker is now commonly associated with an individual who cracks or removes software protection that is designed to prevent unauthorized duplication.
Cyberterrorists hack systems to conduct terrorist activities via network or Internet pathways.
3l. The malicious code attack includes the execution of viruses, worms, Trojan horses, and active Web scripts with the intent to destroy or steal information.
The application of computing and network resources to try every possible combination of options of a password is called a brute crack attack.
One form of e-mail attack that is also a DoS is called a mail spoof, in which an attacker routes large quantities of e-mail to the target.
Sniffers often work on TCP/IP networks, where they’re sometimes called packet sniffers.
A(n) cookie can allow an attacker to collect information on how to access password-protected sites. MULTIPLE CHOICE
Which of the following functions does information security perform for an organization?
Protecting the organization’s ability to function.
Enabling the safe operation of applications implemented on the organization’s IT systems.
Protecting the data the organization collects and uses.
_____ is an integrated system of software, encryption methodologies, and legal agreements that can be used to support the entire information infrastructure of an organization.
______ are software programs that hide their true nature, and reveal their designed behavior only when activated.
Which of the following is an example of a Trojan horse program?
As frustrating as viruses and worms are, perhaps more time and money is spent on resolving virus_________.
4l. Web hosting services are usually arranged with an agreement providing minimum service levels known as a(n)_______.
Complete loss of power for a moment is known as a ______.
Acts of _____ can lead to unauthorized real or virtual actions that enable information gatherers to enter premises or systems they have not been authorized to enter.
There are generally two skill levels among hackers: expert and _____.
One form of online vandalism is _____ operations, which interfere with or disrupt systems to protest the operations, policies, or actions of an organization or government agency.

According to Mark Pollitt, ____ is the premeditated, politically motivated attacks against information, computer systems, computer programs, and data which result in violence against noncombatant targets by subnational groups or clandestine agents.
_____ is any technology that aids in gathering information about a person or organization without their knowledge.
The ____ data file contains the hashed representation of the user’s password.
In a _____ attack, the attacker sends a large number of connection or information requests to a target.
A _____ is an attack in which a coordinated stream of requests is launched against a target from many locations at the same time.
